title: enONE_tutorial
text: hub metabolite, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), can used initiating nucleotide RNA transcription result NAD-capped RNAs (NAD-RNAs). Epitranscriptome-wide profiling NAD-RNAs involves chemo-enzymatic labeling affinity-based enrichment; yet currently available computational analysis adequately remove variations inherently linked capture procedures. , propose spike--based normalization data-driven evaluation framework, enONE, omic-level analysis NAD-capped RNAs. enONE package implemented R publicly available https://github.com/thereallda/enONE.

title: enONE_tutorial
text: tutorial, demonstrate enONE workflow using NAD-RNA-seq data peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) beagle dogs 14 days NMN supplementation water gavage. Notably, included three types spike-RNAs: 1) total RNAs Drosophila melanogaster, invertebrate model organism well-annotated genome sequence, estimating unwanted variation; 2) synthetic RNAs, consisting 5% NAD- relative m7G-capped forms, used determine capture sensitivity; 3) synthetic RNAs, 100% m7G-capped forms, used determine capture specificity (Figure ). 36 samples sequenced Illumina Novaseq 6000. raw data can found GSE221133.  Left panel: study design NMN gavage experiment beagle dogs; Right panel: schematic workflow total RNAs dog PBMCs three sets spike-ins. start reading data, including count matrix metadata. recommended provide assay group samples assay column metadata. Next, use count matrix create Enone object. object serves container contains data (raw normalized counts data) analysis (e.g., normalization performance evaluation score enrichment results) NAD-RNA-seq dataset. constructing Enone object, prefix spike-genes (spike..prefix = "^FB"), id synthetic spike-(synthetic.id = c("Syn1", "Syn2")), id input (input.id = "Input") enrichment (enrich.id = "Enrich") samples can provided. Syn1: 5% NAD-RNA; Syn2: 100% m7G-RNA
code: library(enONE) library(tidyverse) library(patchwork)  # read in metadata and counts matrix counts.mat <- read.csv('../data/Counts.csv', row.names = 1) meta <- read.csv('../data/metadata.csv', comment.char = '#') meta #>     id       condition replicate  assay #> 1   C1   D0_ctrl.Input         1  Input #> 2   C2   D0_ctrl.Input         2  Input #> 3   C3   D0_ctrl.Input         3  Input #> 4   C5   D0_ctrl.Input         4  Input #> 5   C6  D14_ctrl.Input         1  Input #> 6   C7  D14_ctrl.Input         2  Input #> 7   C8  D14_ctrl.Input         3  Input #> 8  C10  D14_ctrl.Input         4  Input #> 9  C11  D0_ctrl.Enrich         1 Enrich #> 10 C12  D0_ctrl.Enrich         2 Enrich #> 11 C13  D0_ctrl.Enrich         3 Enrich #> 12 C15  D0_ctrl.Enrich         4 Enrich #> 13 C16 D14_ctrl.Enrich         1 Enrich #> 14 C17 D14_ctrl.Enrich         2 Enrich #> 15 C18 D14_ctrl.Enrich         3 Enrich #> 16 C20 D14_ctrl.Enrich         4 Enrich #> 17  N1    D0_nmn.Input         1  Input #> 18  N2    D0_nmn.Input         2  Input #> 19  N3    D0_nmn.Input         3  Input #> 20  N4    D0_nmn.Input         4  Input #> 21  N5    D0_nmn.Input         5  Input #> 22  N6   D14_nmn.Input         1  Input #> 23  N7   D14_nmn.Input         2  Input #> 24  N8   D14_nmn.Input         3  Input #> 25  N9   D14_nmn.Input         4  Input #> 26 N10   D14_nmn.Input         5  Input #> 27 N11   D0_nmn.Enrich         1 Enrich #> 28 N12   D0_nmn.Enrich         2 Enrich #> 29 N13   D0_nmn.Enrich         3 Enrich #> 30 N14   D0_nmn.Enrich         4 Enrich #> 31 N15   D0_nmn.Enrich         5 Enrich #> 32 N16  D14_nmn.Enrich         1 Enrich #> 33 N17  D14_nmn.Enrich         2 Enrich #> 34 N18  D14_nmn.Enrich         3 Enrich #> 35 N19  D14_nmn.Enrich         4 Enrich #> 36 N20  D14_nmn.Enrich         5 Enrich # prefix of Drosophila spike-in genes spikeInPrefix <- "^FB"  # create Enone Enone <- createEnone(data = counts.mat,                      bio.group = meta$condition,                      enrich.group = meta$assay,                      batch.group = NULL,                      spike.in.prefix = spikeInPrefix,                      synthetic.id = c("Syn1", "Syn2"),                      input.id = "Input",                      enrich.id = "Enrich"                      ) Enone #> class: Enone  #> dim: 48735 36  #> metadata(0): #> assays(1): '' #> rownames(48735): ENSCAFG00845015183 ENSCAFG00845015195 ... Syn1 Syn2 #> rowData names(3): GeneID SpikeIn Synthetic #> colnames(36): C1 C2 ... N19 N20 #> colData names(5): id condition enrich replicate batch

title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE workflow consists four steps: 1) Quality control; 2) Gene set selection; 3) Normalization procedures; 4) Normalization performance assessment.

title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE initiate quality control step filter lowly-expressed genes. step performed filterByExpr edgeR package. Additionally, outliers can assessed Rosner’s outlier test principal component 1. Since sample flagged outlier, use samples following analysis.
code: keep <- edgeR::filterByExpr(counts.mat, group = meta$condition) Enone <- Enone[keep, ] Enone #> class: Enone  #> dim: 28795 36  #> metadata(0): #> assays(1): '' #> rownames(28795): ENSCAFG00845015217 ENSCAFG00845015316 ... Syn1 Syn2 #> rowData names(3): GeneID SpikeIn Synthetic #> colnames(36): C1 C2 ... N19 N20 #> colData names(5): id condition enrich replicate batch ## ronser's test for outlier assessment vt <- DESeq2::vst(as.matrix(SummarizedExperiment::assay(Enone)), nsub = 20000) pc <- prcomp(t(vt))  ## all samples pass the test EnvStats::rosnerTest(pc$x[,1])$all.stats #>   i        Mean.i     SD.i    Value Obs.Num    R.i+1 lambda.i+1 Outlier #> 1 0 -1.381495e-14 118.1289 144.0791      32 1.219678   2.990585   FALSE #> 2 1 -4.116547e+00 117.2043 138.1465      28 1.213804   2.978183   FALSE #> 3 2 -8.300754e+00 116.2832 133.1332      27 1.216288   2.965315   FALSE

title: enONE_tutorial
text: main enONE function can used perform gene selection, normalization, evaluation. function return selected gene set rowData, normalized count matrix counts slot (return.norm=TRUE), normalization factors (enone_factor slot), evaluation metrics scores enone_metrics enone_scores slots, respectively. Detailed steps described bellow.
code: Enone <- enONE(Enone,                 scaling.method = c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"),                ruv.norm = TRUE, ruv.k = 3,                eval.pam.k = 2:6, eval.pc.n = 3,                return.norm = TRUE                ) #> Gene set selection for normalization and assessment... #> - The number of negative control genes for normalization: 1000  #> - The number of positive evaluation genes: 500  #> - The number of negative evaluation genes: 500  #> Apply normalization... #> Perform assessment...

title: enONE_tutorial
text: gene set selection, enONE defined three sets control genes, including: Negative Control (NegControl): default, enONE define 1,000 least significantly enriched genes Drosophila spike-ins (RNA spike-exogenous organism), ranked edgeR FDR values, negative controls adjustment unwanted variations. Negative Evaluation (NegEvaluation): default, enONE define 500 least significantly varied genes samples interest, ranked edgeR FDR values, negative evaluation genes evaluation unwanted variations. Positive Evaluation (PosEvaluation): default, enONE define 500 significantly enriched genes samples interest, ranked edgeR FDR values, positive evaluation genes evaluation wanted variations. Gene set selection can either automatically defined enONE function auto=TRUE parameter (default), provided neg.control, pos.eval, neg.eval parameters, respectively. Selected gene sets can assessed getGeneSet name gene set (.e., "NegControl", "NegEvaluation", "PosEvaluation").
code: getGeneSet(Enone, "NegControl")[1:5] #> [1] "FBgn0267987" "FBgn0266906" "FBgn0031256" "FBgn0266032" "FBgn0031285"

title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE implements global scaling regression-based methods generation normalization procedures. global scaling normalization procedures, five different scaling procedures implemented, including 1) Total Count (TC); 2) Upper-Quartile (UQ); 3) Trimmed Mean M Values (TMM); 4) DESeq; 5) PossionSeq. Users can perform selected scaling procedures scaling.method parameter. regression-based procedures, enONE use three variants RUV estimate factors unwanted variation, including: 1) RUVg; 2) RUVs; 3) RUVse. instance, can perform RUV selected first two unwanted factors ruv.norm =TRUE, ruv.k=2. RUVse modification RUVs. estimated factors unwanted variation based negative control genes replicate samples assay group (.e., enrichment input), enrichment effect assumed constant. applied normalization methods can assessed list Normalized counts can assessed Counts
code: listNormalization(Enone) #>  [1] "TC"                  "UQ"                  "TMM"                 #>  [4] "DESeq"               "PossionSeq"          "Raw"                 #>  [7] "TC_RUVg_k1"          "TC_RUVs_k1"          "TC_RUVse_k1"         #> [10] "TC_RUVg_k2"          "TC_RUVs_k2"          "TC_RUVse_k2"         #> [13] "TC_RUVg_k3"          "TC_RUVs_k3"          "TC_RUVse_k3"         #> [16] "UQ_RUVg_k1"          "UQ_RUVs_k1"          "UQ_RUVse_k1"         #> [19] "UQ_RUVg_k2"          "UQ_RUVs_k2"          "UQ_RUVse_k2"         #> [22] "UQ_RUVg_k3"          "UQ_RUVs_k3"          "UQ_RUVse_k3"         #> [25] "TMM_RUVg_k1"         "TMM_RUVs_k1"         "TMM_RUVse_k1"        #> [28] "TMM_RUVg_k2"         "TMM_RUVs_k2"         "TMM_RUVse_k2"        #> [31] "TMM_RUVg_k3"         "TMM_RUVs_k3"         "TMM_RUVse_k3"        #> [34] "DESeq_RUVg_k1"       "DESeq_RUVs_k1"       "DESeq_RUVse_k1"      #> [37] "DESeq_RUVg_k2"       "DESeq_RUVs_k2"       "DESeq_RUVse_k2"      #> [40] "DESeq_RUVg_k3"       "DESeq_RUVs_k3"       "DESeq_RUVse_k3"      #> [43] "PossionSeq_RUVg_k1"  "PossionSeq_RUVs_k1"  "PossionSeq_RUVse_k1" #> [46] "PossionSeq_RUVg_k2"  "PossionSeq_RUVs_k2"  "PossionSeq_RUVse_k2" #> [49] "PossionSeq_RUVg_k3"  "PossionSeq_RUVs_k3"  "PossionSeq_RUVse_k3" #> [52] "Raw_RUVg_k1"         "Raw_RUVs_k1"         "Raw_RUVse_k1"        #> [55] "Raw_RUVg_k2"         "Raw_RUVs_k2"         "Raw_RUVse_k2"        #> [58] "Raw_RUVg_k3"         "Raw_RUVs_k3"         "Raw_RUVse_k3" head(Counts(Enone, slot="sample", method="TMM_RUVse_k3"))[,1:5] #>                            C1          C2         C3         C5         C6 #> ENSCAFG00845015217   0.000000   0.0000000   0.000000   0.000000   0.000000 #> ENSCAFG00845015316   0.000000   0.1029219   0.000000   0.000000   0.000000 #> ENSCAFG00845015457 212.078265 190.3361797 144.749655 222.991666 181.939451 #> ENSCAFG00845015550  21.751936  25.4536677  23.452953  19.353599  23.024178 #> ENSCAFG00845015637   3.198595   3.7444409   3.499004   3.128450   4.371144 #> ENSCAFG00845015701   3.750302   4.2315408   4.113948   5.610714   5.773797

title: enONE_tutorial
text: evaluate performance normalization, enONE leverages eight normalization performance metrics related different aspects distribution gene expression measures. eight metrics listed : BIO_SIM: Similarity biological groups. average silhouette width clusters defined bio.group, computed Euclidean distance metric first 3 expression PCs (default). Large values BIO_SIM desirable. EN_SIM: Similarity enrichment groups. average silhouette width clusters defined en.group, computed Euclidean distance metric first 3 expression PCs (default). Large values EN_SIM desirable. BAT_SIM: Similarity batch groups. average silhouette width clusters defined batch.group, computed Euclidean distance metric first 3 expression PCs (default). Low values BAT_SIM desirable. PAM_SIM: Similarity PAM clustering groups. maximum average silhouette width clusters defined PAM clustering (cluster eval.pam.k), computed Euclidean distance metric first 3 expression PCs (default). Large values BAT_SIM desirable. WV_COR: Preservation biological variation. R2 measure regression first 3 expression PCs first eval.pc.n PCs positive evaluation genes (PosEvaluation) sub-matrix raw count. Large values WV_COR desirable. UV_COR: Removal unwanted variation. R2 measure regression first 3 expression PCs first eval.pc.n PCs negative evaluation genes (NegEvaluation) sub-matrix raw count. Low values UV_COR desirable. RLE_MED: mean squared-median Relative Log Expression (RLE). Low values RLE_MED desirable. RLE_IQR: variance inter-quartile range (IQR) RLE. Low values RLE_IQR desirable. Evaluation metrics can assessed getMetrics Evaluation score average rank performance metrics, can assessed getScore

what: Select the suitable normalization for subsequent analysis
title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE provides biplot exploit full space normalization methods, can turn interactive mode interactive=TRUE.  plot, point corresponds normalization procedure colored performance score (mean eight scone performance metric ranks). blue arrows correspond PCA loadings performance metrics. direction length blue arrow can interpreted measure much metric contributed first two PCs , use top-ranked procedure TMM_RUVse_k3 downstream analysis. noted, normalized counts returned enONE run step (.e., return.norm=FALSE), can manually perform normalization method, e.g.,
code: # get performance score enScore <- getScore(Enone) # perform PCA based on evaluation score, excluding BAT_SIM column (3) for no batch information provided, and SCORE column (9). pca.eval <- prcomp(enScore[,-c(3, 9)], scale = TRUE) # pca biplot PCA_Biplot(pca.eval, score = enScore$SCORE, interactive = FALSE) # select normalization norm.method <- rownames(enScore[1,])  # get normalized counts norm.data <- Counts(Enone, slot = 'sample', method = norm.method)  # get normalization factors norm.factors <- getFactor(Enone, slot = 'sample', method = norm.method)  norm.method #> [1] "TMM_RUVs_k2" # perform normalization Enone <- UseNormalization(Enone, slot = 'sample', method = 'TMM_RUVse_k3') # get normalized counts norm.data <- Counts(Enone, slot = 'sample', method = norm.method)

title: enONE_tutorial
text: perform PCA based count matrix sample interest normalization, demonstrating effect normalization.
code: # create sample name, e.g., D0_ctrl.Input.1 samples_name <- paste(Enone$condition, Enone$replicate, sep='.')  # PCA for raw count p1 <- PCAplot(log1p(Counts(Enone, slot='sample', 'Raw')),              color = Enone$condition,             label = NULL, vst.norm = FALSE) +    ggtitle('Before normalization')  # PCA for normalized count p2 <- PCAplot(log1p(norm.data),              color = Enone$condition,             label = NULL, vst.norm = FALSE) +    ggtitle('After normalization')  # combine two plots p1 + p2

title: enONE_tutorial
text: enONE package can help find enrichment genes biological groups via differential expression. can identify genes significantly increased enrichment samples compared input samples. FindEnrichment automates processes groups provided bio.group. default, enriched genes (NAD-RNA ) defined fold change normalized transcript counts ≥ 2 (logfc.cutoff = 1), FDR < 0.05 (p.cutoff = 0.05) enrichment samples compared input samples. Use getEnrichment retrieve list enrichment result tables. enrichment table data.frame list genes rows, associated information columns (GeneID, logFC, p-values, etc.). following columns present table: GeneID: ID genes. logFC: log2 fold-change enrichment input samples. Positive values indicate gene highly enriched enrichment group. logCPM: log2 CPM (counts per million) average expression samples. LR: Likelihood ratio likelihood ratio test. PValue: p-value likelihood ratio test. FDR: False discovery rate p-value, default “BH” method applied. convert list enrichment result tables data frame long format, enONE package provide reduceRes function task. Finally, can use BetweenStatPlot compare global extent NAD-RNA modification level groups.
code: # find all enriched genes Enone <- FindEnrichment(Enone, slot='sample', method = norm.method,                          logfc.cutoff = 1, p.cutoff = 0.05)  # get filtered enrichment results res.sig.ls <- getEnrichment(Enone, slot='sample', filter=TRUE)  # count number of enrichment in each group unlist(lapply(res.sig.ls, nrow)) #>   D0_ctrl.Enrich_D0_ctrl.Input D14_ctrl.Enrich_D14_ctrl.Input  #>                           2312                           2232  #>     D0_nmn.Enrich_D0_nmn.Input   D14_nmn.Enrich_D14_nmn.Input  #>                           2841                           2312 head(res.sig.ls[[1]]) #>               GeneID    logFC    logCPM       LR        PValue           FDR #> 1 ENSCAFG00845007784 3.055073  8.717684 878.7366 4.114221e-193 5.972203e-189 #> 2 ENSCAFG00845002083 3.113414 12.584709 664.1688 1.852380e-146 1.344457e-142 #> 3 ENSCAFG00845009430 2.460452  7.643004 591.0913 1.450530e-130 7.018629e-127 #> 4 ENSCAFG00845018743 2.407697  9.528866 578.4103 8.315389e-128 3.017655e-124 #> 5 ENSCAFG00845021389 2.759788  8.554199 564.7637 7.733279e-125 2.245125e-121 #> 6 ENSCAFG00845000887 2.353257  7.351376 553.5413 2.136043e-122 5.167800e-119 # simplify group id names(res.sig.ls) <- c('D0.Water', 'D14.Water', 'D0.NMN', 'D14.NMN')  # logfc.col specify the name of logFC column nad_df1 <- reduceRes(res.sig.ls, logfc.col = 'logFC')  # convert the Group column as factor nad_df1$Group <- factor(nad_df1$Group, levels = unique(nad_df1$Group))  # draw plot bxp1 <- BetweenStatPlot(nad_df1, x='Group', y='logFC', color='Group',                          step.increase = 0.6, add.p = 'p',                          comparisons = list(c('D0.Water', 'D14.Water'),                                             c('D0.NMN', 'D14.NMN'))) bxp1

title: enONE_tutorial
text: Since synthetic RNAs, one 5% NAD-caps another 100% m7G-caps, included, can use spike-ins determine capture sensitivity specificity. synEnrichment calculate enrichment levels synthetic spike-ins given normalization method. DotPlot can used visualize enrichment levels synthetic spike-.  Syn1, contained 5% NAD-RNA, significantly enriched, whereas enrichment found Syn2 made 100% m7G-RNA.
code: # compute synthetic spike-in enrichment syn_level <- synEnrichment(Enone, method=norm.method, log=TRUE)  # transform to long format syn_df <- as.data.frame(syn_level) %>%    rownames_to_column("syn_id") %>%    pivot_longer(cols = -syn_id,                names_to = "id",                values_to = "logFC") %>%    left_join(meta[,c("id","condition")], by="id")  # remove suffix of condition for simplification syn_df$condition <- gsub("\\..*", "", syn_df$condition)  # rename facet label samples_label <- setNames(c('5% NAD-RNA', '100% m7G-RNA'),                            nm=c('Syn1', 'Syn2'))  # draw dotplot DotPlot(syn_df, x="condition", y="logFC", fill="condition") +   facet_wrap(~syn_id, labeller = as_labeller(samples_label)) +   theme(legend.position = 'none') #> Bin width defaults to 1/30 of the range of the data. Pick better value with #> `binwidth`. # save Enone data save(Enone, file="data/Enone.RData")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Li D (2023). enONE: Epitranscriptional NAD-capped RNA analysis spike-based Omic-level Normalization Evaluation. R package version 0.1.0, https://thereallda.github.io/enONE/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {enONE: Epitranscriptional NAD-capped RNA analysis by spike-in based Omic-level Normalization and Evaluation},   author = {Dean Li},   year = {2023},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://thereallda.github.io/enONE/}, }

what: Epitranscriptional NAD-capped RNA analysis by spike-in based Omic-level Normalization and Evaluation
title: Epitranscriptional NAD-capped RNA analysis by spike-in based Omic-level Normalization and Evaluation
text: enONE R package performing spike-based normalization NAD-capped RNA sequencing data, well comparing ranking performance different normalization strategies. enONE also provides toolkit handle NAD-RNA sequencing data.

title: Epitranscriptional NAD-capped RNA analysis by spike-in based Omic-level Normalization and Evaluation
text: can install development version enONE GitHub : Tutorial can found https://thereallda.github.io/enONE/
code: # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("thereallda/enONE")

what: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
code: ApplyNormalization(   data,   scaling.method = c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"),   ruv.norm = TRUE,   ruv.k = 1,   ruv.drop = 0,   control.idx = NULL,   sc.idx = NULL,   enrich.idx = NULL,   spike.in.prefix = NULL )

title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
text: data un-normalized count data matrix shape n x p, n number samples p number features. scaling.method Vector normalization methods applied data. Available methods : c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"). Select one multiple methods. default normalization methods applied. ruv.norm Whether perform RUV normalization. ruv.k number factors unwanted variation estimated data. ruv.drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default drop first singular value represent difference enrichment input. control.idx Vector negative control genes RUV normalization. sc.idx numeric matrix specifying replicate samples compute count differences used estimate factors unwanted variation. enrich.idx Matrix two rows indicating column index enrichment input samples raw/normalized count data matrix. first row column index input second row column index enrichment samples. spike..prefix character specify prefix spike-id.

title: Applies normalization on sequencing data — ApplyNormalization
text: List objects containing normalized data associated normalization factors.

title: Assessments of normalization performance — AssessNormalization
code: AssessNormalization(   data.ls,   bio.group = NULL,   enrich.group = NULL,   batch.group = NULL,   eval.pam.k = 2:6,   eval.pc.n = 3,   log = TRUE,   pos.eval.set = NULL,   neg.eval.set = NULL )

title: Assessments of normalization performance — AssessNormalization
text: data.ls List containing normalized counts adjust factors adjusting unwanted variation. Output ApplyNormalization. bio.group Vector index indicating column index samples biological groups raw/normalized count data matrix. enrich.group Vector index indicating column index enrichment input samples raw/normalized count data matrix. batch.group Vector index indicating column index batch groups raw/normalized count data matrix. eval.pam.k Integer vector integers indicates number clusters PAM clustering performance evaluation, default: 2:6. eval.pc.n Integer indicates evaluation metrics calculated first nth PCs, default: 3. log Whether perform log2-transformation 1 offset data matrix, default: TRUE. pos.eval.set Vector genes id. neg.eval.set Vector genes id.

title: Assessments of normalization performance — AssessNormalization
text: List containing metrics matrix ranking matrix, sorted score methods top bottom.

what: Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
title: Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
code: BetweenStatPlot(   data,   x,   y,   color,   palette = NULL,   test = c("wilcox.test", "t.test", "none"),   add.p = c("p", "p.adj"),   comparisons = NULL,   step.increase = 0.3 )

title: Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
text: data data frame (tibble). x grouping variable data. y value variable data. color color variable data. palette color palette different groups. test Perform wilcoxon rank sum test t-test test, must one c("wilcox.test", "t.test", "none"). add.p Label p-value adjusted p-value, must one c("p", "p.adj"). comparisons list length-2 vectors specifying groups interest compared. example compare groups "" vs "B" "B" vs "C", argument follow: comparisons = list(c("", "B"), c("B", "C")) step.increase Numeric vector increase fraction total height every additional comparison minimize overlap.

title: Box-violin plot comparing values between groups — BetweenStatPlot
Accessor for the
code: Counts(object, slot = c("sample", "spike_in"), method)  Counts(object, slot = c("sample", "spike_in"), method) <- value  # S4 method for Enone,character,character Counts(object, slot = c("sample", "spike_in"), method)  # S4 method for Enone,character,character,matrix Counts(object, slot = c("sample", "spike_in"), method) <- value

title: Accessor for the
text: object Enone. slot slot get, one sample spike_in. method counts matrix get, must one raw normalized counts matrix presented selected slot. value Raw normalized counts matrix.

text: Find enriched genes enrich input samples

title: Find enriched genes between enrich and input samples — FindEnrichment
code: FindEnrichment(   object,   slot = c("sample", "spike_in"),   method,   logfc.cutoff = 1,   p.cutoff = 0.05,   ... )

title: Find enriched genes between enrich and input samples — FindEnrichment
text: object object. slot slot, one sample spike_in. method normalization methods, must one methods presented selected slot. logfc.cutoff Filter genes least X-fold difference (log2-scale) two groups samples, default: 1. p.cutoff Filter genes p.cutoff adjusted p-value, default: 0.05. ... Additional parameters can passed edgeRDE.

title: Find enriched genes between enrich and input samples — FindEnrichment
Gene set selection — GeneSelection
text: Select negative control genes RUV normalization, positive negative evaluation genes assessment.

title: Gene set selection — GeneSelection
code: GeneSelection(object, n.neg.control, n.pos.eval, n.neg.eval)

title: Gene set selection — GeneSelection
text: object Enone object n.neg.control Number negative control genes RUV normalization, default: 1000. n.pos.eval Number positive evaluation genes wanted variation assessment, default: 500. n.neg.eval Number negative evaluation genes unwanted variation assessment, default: 500.

what: Biplot of individuals and variables — PCA_Biplot

Biplot of individuals and variables — PCA_Biplot
code: PCA_Biplot(object, score, pt.label = TRUE, interactive = FALSE)

title: Biplot of individuals and variables — PCA_Biplot
text: object PCA object returned prcomp. score Vector performance scores Enone evaluation score. pt.label Whether plot point labels, default: TRUE. interactive Whether demonstrate plot interactively, default: FALSE.

title: Biplot of individuals and variables — PCA_Biplot

what: PCA plot from counts matrix — PCAplot
title: PCA plot from counts matrix — PCAplot
PCA plot from counts matrix — PCAplot
code: PCAplot(   object,   use.pc = c(1, 2),   color = NULL,   label = NULL,   shape = NULL,   vst.norm = FALSE,   palette = NULL,   repel = TRUE )

title: PCA plot from counts matrix — PCAplot
text: object count matrix. use.pc two PCs used, default PC1 x-axis PC2 y-axis. color Vector indicates color mapping samples, default NULL. label Vector sample names labels, default NULL. shape Vector indicates shape mapping samples, default NULL. vst.norm Whether perform vst transformation, default FALSE. palette color palette different groups. repel Whether use ggrepel avoid overlapping text labels , default TRUE.

title: PCA plot from counts matrix — PCAplot
PCA plot from counts matrix — PCAplot
text: Perform PCA based matrix using prcomp, visualized scatter plot.

title: Esimate sequencing depth — PS.Est.Depth
code: PS.Est.Depth(n, iter = 5, ct.sum = 5, ct.mean = 0.5)

title: Esimate sequencing depth — PS.Est.Depth
text: n data matrix. rows counts gene, columns counts experiment. iter Number iterations used. Default value: 5. default value usually good choice. ct.sum total number reads gene across experiments <= ct.sum, gene considered estimating sequencing depth. Default value: 5. ct.mean mean number reads gene across experiments <= ct.mean, gene considered estimating sequencing depth. Default value: 0.5.

title: Apply specific normalization method — UseNormalization
code: UseNormalization(object, slot = c("sample", "spike_in"), method)

title: Apply specific normalization method — UseNormalization
text: object Enone object. slot slot, one sample spike_in. method normalization methods perform.

Enone object and constructor — Enone-class
text: Enone object extends SummarizedExperiment class. createEnone easy constructor Enone object

title: Enone object and constructor — Enone-class
code: createEnone(   data,   bio.group,   enrich.group,   batch.group = NULL,   spike.in.prefix = NULL,   input.id = "Input",   enrich.id = "Enrich",   synthetic.id = NULL )

title: Enone object and constructor — Enone-class
text: data un-normalized count data matrix shape n x p, n number samples p number features. bio.group Vector samples group, e.g., c("Young.Input","Young.Enrich","Old.Input","Old.Enrich"). enrich.group Vector enrichment group, e.g., c("Input","Enrich","Input","Enrich"). batch.group Vector samples batch, e.g., c("","","B","B"), default: NULL. spike..prefix character specify prefix spike-id, e.g., "^FB" stands fly spike-id, default: NULL. input.id Input library id, must consistent enrich.group, e.g., "Input". enrich.id Enrich library id, must consistent enrich.group, e.g., "Enrich". synthetic.id Vector synthetic RNA id, e.g. c("Syn1","Syn2"), default: NULL.

title: Enone object and constructor — Enone-class
text: Description slot: assay SummarizedExperiment::Assays object, contains counts. counts list holding raw/normalized counts sample spike_in. enone_factor list holding normalization factors sample spike_in. enone_metrics data frame normalization methods row metrics columns. enone_score data frame normalization methods row scores columns. enrichment list holding differential analysis results. enrichment_filtered lists holding filtered differential analysis results. parameter list parameters.

title: Statistics summary (mean and +/- sd) — .mean_sd
code: .mean_sd(x)

title: Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE
code: edgeRDE(   counts,   group,   norm.factors = NULL,   adjust.factors = NULL,   design.formula = NULL,   contrast.df = NULL,   coef = NULL,   logfc.cutoff = 1,   p.cutoff = 0.05,   only.pos = TRUE )

title: Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE
text: counts un-normalized counts data matrix. group Vector length p mapping columns counts corresponding samples group. norm.factors Vector normalization factors p length. adjust.factors Matrix column indicates adjusting factors estimated RUV. design.formula Formula contrast.df Data frame contrast, extracting results first column vs. second column. coef Integer character vector indicating coefficients linear model tested equal zero. Values must columns column names design. logfc.cutoff Filter genes least X-fold difference (log2-scale) two groups samples, default: 1. p.cutoff Filter genes Y adjusted p-value, default: 0.05. .pos return positive genes filtered results res.sig.ls, default: TRUE.

title: Wrapper of edgeR procedure — edgeRDE
text: List containing differential analysis object, result table filtered result table.

what: Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE
title: Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE
Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE
code: enONE(   object,   auto = TRUE,   return.norm = FALSE,   n.neg.control = 1000,   n.pos.eval = 500,   n.neg.eval = 500,   neg.control = NULL,   pos.eval = NULL,   neg.eval = NULL,   scaling.method = c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"),   ruv.norm = TRUE,   ruv.k = 1,   ruv.drop = 0,   eval.pam.k = 2:6,   eval.pc.n = 3 )

title: Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE
text: object Enone object. auto Whether automatically select negative control, positive evaluation negative evaluation genes, default: TRUE. return.norm Whether return normalized counts object. default, return normalized counts reducing memory costs. n.neg.control Number negative control genes RUV normalization, default: 1000. n.pos.eval Number positive evaluation genes wanted variation assessment, default: 500. n.neg.eval Number negative evaluation genes unwanted variation assessment, default: 500. neg.control Vector negative control genes' id RUV normalization, default: NULL. pos.eval Vector positive evaluation genes' id wanted variation assessment, default: NULL. neg.eval Vector negative evaluation genes' id unwanted variation assessment, default: NULL. scaling.method Vector scaling methods applied data. Available methods : c("TC", "UQ", "TMM", "DESeq", "PossionSeq"). Select one multiple methods. default scaling methods applied. ruv.norm Whether perform RUV normalization. ruv.k number factors unwanted variation estimated data, default: 1. ruv.drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default: 0. eval.pam.k Integer vector integers indicates number clusters PAM clustering performance evaluation, default: 2:6. eval.pc.n Integer indicates evaluation metrics calculated first nth PCs, default: 3.

title: Normalization and assessment in one function — enONE

what: Remove unwanted variation using control genes — enRUVg
title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes — enRUVg
Remove unwanted variation using control genes — enRUVg
code: enRUVg(object, log = TRUE, k = 1, tolerance = 1e-08, control.idx, drop = 1)

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes — enRUVg
text: object counts matrix. log Whether perform log2-transformation 1 offset data matrix, default: TRUE. k number factors unwanted variation estimated data. tolerance Tolerance selection number positive singular values, .e., singular value must larger tolerance considered positive. control.idx ID control genes. drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default drop first singular value represent difference enrichment input

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes — enRUVg
text: list contain matrix unwanted factors (W) corrected counts matrix (normalizedCounts).

what: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
code: enRUVs(   object,   log = TRUE,   k = 2,   tolerance = 1e-08,   control.idx,   sc.idx,   drop = 1 )

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
text: object counts matrix. log Whether perform log2-transformation 1 offset data matrix, default: TRUE. k number factors unwanted variation estimated data. tolerance Tolerance selection number positive singular values, .e., singular value must larger tolerance considered positive. control.idx ID control genes. sc.idx numeric matrix specifying replicate samples compute count differences used estimate factors unwanted variation (see details). drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default drop first singular value represent difference enrichment input

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
text: list contain matrix unwanted factors (W) corrected counts matrix (normalizedCounts).

title: Remove unwanted variation using control genes within replicates — enRUVs
text: row sc.idx correspond set replicate samples. number columns size largest set replicates; rows smaller sets padded -1 values. example, sets replicate samples (1,2,3),(4,5),(6,7,8), scIdx 1 2 3 4 5 -1 6 7 8

title: Accessor of enrichment results — getEnrichment
text: object Enone. slot slot get, one sample spike_in. filter Whether get filtered enrichment, default FALSE.

title: Perform RUV normalization — normRUV
code: normRUV(   data,   control.idx = NULL,   sc.idx = NULL,   method = c("RUVg", "RUVs", "RUVse"),   k = 1,   drop = 0,   log = TRUE )

title: Perform RUV normalization — normRUV
text: data un-normalized count data matrix shape n x p, n number samples p number features. control.idx Vector control genes' id. sc.idx numeric matrix specifying replicate samples compute count differences used estimate factors unwanted variation. method Perform RUVg RUVs normalization. k number factors unwanted variation estimated data. drop number singular values drop estimation unwanted variation, default drop first singular value represent difference enrichment input. log Whether perform log2-transformation 1 offset data matrix (default: TRUE), normalized counts returned non-log format.

title: Perform RUV normalization — normRUV
text: List containing normalized counts adjust factors adjusting unwanted variation.
